moves.1. e4 e5 2. d4 exd4 3. c3 d5: Taubenhaus declines Mieses' offer of a tasty Danish.
moves.4. exd5 Qxd5 5. cxd4 Nc6: After the initial flurry, development begins.
moves.6... Bg4: Pinning the Knight and preparing to castle.
moves.8. Nc3: Looking to drive off the Queen.
moves.8... Qh5: Targeting the K-side, where he thinks Mieses might castle.
moves.10... Nf6: Taubenhaus clears *his* first rank and connects his Rooks.
moves.11. Rc1: Moving into position on the half-open QB file and targeting Black's King.
moves.11... Rhe8: Seizing the fully open K file and targeting *White's* King.
moves.13. Rxc6: Mieses' sacrifice of the Exchange ensures his attack gets there first.
moves.14. Nxa7+: Opening a line for the KB to join the attack. If Taubenhaus moves his King to the QN file, it will be cut off from pieces that can defend it. So...
moves.14... Kd7: ...he moves here, seeking shelter among his cluster of pieces.
moves.15. Ne5+: The winning stroke. If Taubenhaus gives back the Exchange with 15... RxN 16 PxR, he is behind a Pawn and Mieses' passed QRP gives him a winning advantage in an end game. If Taubenhaus moves his K to the King file, 16 NxB wins a piece. So Taubenhaus resigns at once.
